conclusion: Magnetic flux linked with the part of the loop inside the field is Φ = (B · ½L²).
The field is directed into the page and is decreasing uniformly at the rate k = –dB/dt.
Induced emf around the whole loop is |ε| = |–dΦ/dt| = ½kL².
The loop is broken by an ideal capacitor C, so no steady conduction path exists.
Charge is displaced and the capacitor becomes charged until the potential difference across it equals the induced emf.
Instantaneous current i obeys i = C (dV/dt), but V = ε, so i = C (dε/dt).
Since ε = ½kL² is constant in time, dε/dt = 0, hence i = 0.
Induced emf exists, but after an infinitesimal charging transient no further current flows through the wire.
Magnitude of induced emf in the loop: ε = ½ k L².
Current in the loop (after the very short charging transient): i = 0.
